awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2025 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC 25) 19th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI 25)
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Association presents conferences at the forefront of computing innovation and research that build collaborations between researchers and practitioners from industry, government, and academia. These events provide educational, mentorship, and networking opportunities of very high value to graduate students in the computer sciences who attend. To help increase the representation and participation of these students, this proposal provides funding to assist approximately 34 US-based graduate students to attend each of the following events:

● 2025 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (ATC ‘25)
● 19th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI ‘25)


The knowledge shared and advanced at these conferences has practical and meaningful application to many tools used in daily life, as well as to the ethical, cultural, and social ramifications of computing technology. This grant allows the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. USENIX is an open access organization, and all research and results presented and published at these events are freely available to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in July 2025, specifically the 2025 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC ‘25) and the 19th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI ‘25).

USENIX ATC ‘25 took place July 7-9, 2025, in Boston, MA. USENIX ATC ‘25 brought together leading systems researchers for the presentation of cutting-edge systems research and the opportunity to gain insight into a wealth of must-know topics, including virtualization, system and network management and troubleshooting, cloud and edge computing, security, privacy, and trust, mobile and wireless, and more. The program also included papers that integrate and systematize existing knowledge to provide new insights into previously studied areas. 

OSDI ‘25 also occurred on July 7-9, 2025, in Boston (co-located with USENIX ATC ‘25). OSDI gathered professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds in a premier forum to discuss the design, implementation, and implications of systems software. The symposium emphasizes innovative research and quantified or insightful experiences in systems design and implementation. Topics included security, cloud computing, transaction support, storage, networking, formal verification of systems, graph processing, system support for machine learning, programming languages, troubleshooting, and the design and implementation of operating systems.

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and essential part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work. This grant enabled students who would otherwise have been unable to attend the conferences due to financial constraints to participate, thereby extending the impact of the research presented to a broader audience of young researchers. Students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including a student meetup, mentorship opportunities, poster sessions, and receptions. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. USENIX covered registration costs by providing grant recipients with a code providing full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist with costs related to travel and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before completing payments. 

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics,

  • Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster),

  • Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant’s research,

  • Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months,

  • Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,

  • Degree program (graduate students prioritized) and financial need.

NSF funds supported a total of 42 grants for students to participate in USENIX ATC ‘25 and OSDI ‘25.  The financial support from NSF allowed us to grant awards to many more qualified students than we would have been able to otherwise. 

  • For USENIX ATC ‘25, USENIX received 56 grant applications from students and awarded 23 grants. The NSF funds of $20,800 covered 17 of these grants, representing 11 educational institutions. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a US university.

  • For OSDI ‘25, USENIX received 86 grant applications from students and awarded 52 student grants. The NSF funds of $29,200 covered 25 of these grants, representing 20 institutions. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university.
